ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Evolutionary genetics (quantitative genetics, in-depth analysis of Hardy-Weinberg model and how it changes if you relax some assumptions), molecular mechanisms of evolution, protein space, evolutionary medicine, how cultural and biological evolution are intertwined

I learned about population genetics, evolutionary dynamics and theory, and evolutionary medicine. The class taught both tools evolutionary biologists use (fitness landscapes, equations to model population genetics, etc.) and the theory underlying those tools.
Better understanding of evolutionary biology, its importance, and its implications
Both the math-based concepts and evolution and also the more theoretical approaches.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Both professors are great lecturers-- Prof. Ogbunu's lecturing style was definitely the highlight of this class. The class had a very strong overall structure where every class/week was a discrete topic and we stayed on track, so I feel we learned a lot/covered a lot of topics even though the class was not a very large time commitment. Another strength was the grading system for the first half of class: psets were optional, but helpful to learn the material and counted as bonus points for the first exam, so if you felt confident on a topic you could skip a pset with no consequences, but if you wanted practice you could earn a few extra points. The exams were challenging, but fair. 
The only weakness of the class was that I felt discussion section was often unnecessary, especially for the second half of the class (and it got cancelled all the time on short notice). I think either this class should have more consistent homework so we could have something to talk about in section, or have section be completely optional and more of an open office hour with the TFs.

It was a little difficult to switch instructors halfway through the course; both instructors are good teachers and taught their material well, but their styles and expectations were completely different, which was just a bit tough to adjust to.

One of the weaknesses was that it was a 2hr long class once a week, I think it might have benefitted from being a 50 min class twice a week. 
One of the strengths was that the instructors were very knowledgeable and took time to explain concepts well. 

The biggest strength was the ability to revise homework problems, given that we explained why we got something wrong and showed greater understanding.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yeah pretty chill class if you study a little bit before the tests

Definitely! It's a great fifth class-- it's not a big time commitment (meets once a week and minimal work outside of class), but it's super interesting and comprehensive. Going to Prof. Ogbunu's lectures felt like a treat rather than a class meeting. Don't be scared away by the math in the first week or two-- most of it is conceptual, so if you understand what is happening in the biology it's really not too bad.
Sure, but only if they are really interested in Evolutionary Bio.
